div.p: Then Cadien took Genereux who on account of his having a frozen Toe when he left bear Lake could not proceed any further than the Gros Roche's where he remained with Grand Chefre[.] [F]rom whence Cadien came with 2 Indians[.] [H]e says that this is the third day Since he has Eat nothing – therefore I gave him a Prey[.] Mr Clarke writes me that my men first arrived at Bear Lake on the 26th of Jany after having ran astray to blue Fish owing to the ignorance they were in of the road the Indian having left them on the way – being fearful of being Killed for food – as the Provns was lowering very fast & the men little able to march[.] [T]hey put to go to the Gros Roché only from this 13 days[.] [T]hese are Smart fellows & merit some reward[.] [N]ews from below says – Poor expectations are entertained of making returns, particularly at Bear Lake – where no less than three widowers have been made unknown to themselves & perhaps involuntarily[.] w This happened by the desertion of three Ladies last Spring after the departure of the Canoe from that Place[.] [A]t the head of this party was Mrs Clarke with a Great & valuable Booty – which they had the care of taking from the Shop & the Husbands private property[.] [W]ith this These Summer Clerks have made the best of their way to the River au Peau de Lievries Lands – where it is supposed they will perform great Feats – not to the advantage of the Compy Interest[.] These are indeed Master Pieces – a woman Clerk had not long ago been recommended & even extolled as one of the best Tools that could be employed in charge of a Post for the Summer[.] I believe these Gentlemen will now be convinced of their own conviction to the Contrary[.] It is also said that three men, (Canadians) & 3 Indians are gone for them[.] Mr Henry is en decouverte on the Rocky Mountain[.] Fine weather[.]

Sunday 7th[.] Arranged Martin & Gibeau to be off tomorrow with the express to Slave Lake[.] Gave them 37lb Pimican 20 Hares 4 meases Amn 1 old Gun 1 half Ax 1Pr Shoes & 2 Pr Racquettes[.] In the evening Martin accused Gibeau of having Stolen Grease & Fat which he had cooked for me[.] This happened at the a time when I was taken up with the loss of my little Boy – being myself indisposed – I allowed him to go to the Store for Hares for our own substa sistance[.] [H]e denied it – but at length confessed that he had taken only about ½lb[.] The other maintained that he had Stolen much
